title: one
instructions:
You're alone in a thick, foggy forest as night falls, where shadows look like monsters.
The crunch of leaves under your shoes sounds way too loud, giving away every move.
Your breathing comes fast and rough—you're lost, no path, no phone signal at all.
A far-off howl cuts through the air, ice running down your back.
Your heart slams hard and uneven, every muscle ready for something bad.
You speed up, branches slapping your face and cutting skin.
All at once, you hear footsteps behind—not an animal, but a person, steady and getting closer.
Panic floods in; you think: They're hunting me, I'll never get out.
Your legs ache, chest squeezed tight like it's crushing you.
You trip on roots, crash down hard, knees bleeding.
The footsteps turn louder, right behind.
You claw back up, dizzy, fog growing thicker around you.
Sweat soaks your shirt, mixing with pure terror.
A weak light glows ahead—rescue? Or a trick?
Your brain fills with nightmares: caught, hurt bad, left to rot.
Now you hear their breathing, close and hot against your neck.
You run without seeing, thorns ripping your arms and legs.
Helplessness hits like a wave—no one knows where you are.
Tears sting your eyes as the trees press in, choking you.

title: two
instructions:
It's midnight in your isolated cabin during a brutal winter storm.
Snow piles against the windows, blotting out the world.
You're curled under blankets, but a sharp pain stabs your abdomen, sudden and unrelenting.
You clutch your side, gasping as waves of agony ripple through you.
Alone—no neighbors for miles, roads impassable.
Your phone's dead from the power outage.
Nausea builds, sweat beading despite the cold.
You think, This is appendicitis; I'll die here untreated.
Stumbling to the bathroom, you vomit violently, legs weakening.
The wind howls like a beast outside, mocking your vulnerability.
You collapse on the floor, vision spotting black.
Heart racing, you imagine infection spreading, organs failing.
Desperation claws at you; you crawl to the door, but the blizzard rages, sealing you in.
Pain intensifies, a fire inside.
Memories of family flood your mind—regrets, goodbyes unsaid.
You feel trapped in your own body, abandoned.
Shivers rack you, mixing with fever.
The night stretches endless; will morning bring rescue, or just silence?

title: three
instructions:
Tear gas smoke chokes the air.
You're cut off from your friends, shoved hard by the rushing crowd.
Panic climbs fast as bodies crush in, stealing your breath.
A bottle smashes close, glass spraying everywhere.
Your heart slams against your ribs, mouth bone-dry.
You slip into an alley—but it's blocked, walls covered in tags closing you in like a trap.
Shouts ring out: Run! They're coming!
You think: They'll trample me or drag me away.
Sirens scream, everything wild.
You flatten against the rough brick, taking tiny breaths, terrified they'll spot you.
Footsteps get nearer—is it help or danger?
Adrenaline hits hard, your hands won't stop shaking.
The mob surges back, pulling you right into the chaos.
Elbows dig in, boots stomp inches from your feet.
Fear locks tight: you'll disappear in this nightmare forever.
You see a way out, but flames from a burning trash can block it.
Hopelessness crashes down—no way free.
Pictures of getting hurt, never seeing loved ones again fill your head.
The night turns into pure madness, being alone makes every danger feel worse.

High in the sky, your plane jerks hard, turbulence slamming it like a huge fist.
Seatbelt light blares red; oxygen masks drop down, swinging uselessly.
You clutch the armrests, knuckles pale, as the plane drops then shoots up.
Screams explode everywhere—including yours.

title: four
instructions:
In the dark parking garage after work, the fluorescent lights buzz and flicker.
You dig for your keys, feeling nervous prickles on your skin.
Slow, heavy footsteps echo behind you.
You look back: a hooded person, face hidden in shadow.
Your heart pounds loud in your ears.
You walk faster to your car, but it seems much farther away.
The figure keeps the same speed, getting closer.
Panic hits hard; your bag falls, things spill everywhere.
“Hey!” a rough voice shouts.
You think: kidnapped, gone forever, no one will find me.
The doors look miles away.
You start running, heels clicking loudly on the concrete.
They speed up too, breathing heavy and close.
You reach your car—the lock won’t turn.
Your hands shake badly, the key slips.
They grab your shoulder; you scream and twist free.
Adrenaline rushes through you, your vision narrows.
You fight back, scratching and pushing, but it’s no use.
They pin you against the cold car door. You feel completely helpless.
Thoughts of home and safety disappear.
No one is coming. Your screams bounce off the empty walls.
You wonder if anyone will even look for you, or if you’ll just be another missing person story.
In your quiet study at night, a sudden violent cough explodes.
Blood spatters onto your shaking hand.
Your chest feels like it’s on fire; every breath comes short and whistling.
You’re completely by yourself.
You stumble to the mirror: face ghost-white, eyes huge with fear.
Your heart beats wild and uneven—is this a heart attack? An aneurysm bursting?
You reach for the phone to call for help, but no words come out, only desperate gasps.
The phone falls and breaks with a crack.
Pain spreads in heavy waves through your body.
The edges of your sight go black.
One clear thought cuts through: I’m dying alone, with no one to say goodbye to.
You drop to your hands and knees, crawling toward the door.
The room spins wildly.
Memories flood in: your child’s happy laugh, now sounding like a sad, distant echo.

title: four
instructions:
Deep underground in a subway car during rush hour, the train screeches to a halt midway through a tunnel.
Lights flicker, then die, plunging all into pitch black.
Murmurs turn to gasps; your phone flashlight reveals worried faces.
No announcement—silence breeds fear.
Air thickens, stuffy.
You feel the walls pressing, claustrophobia clawing.
Heart races as minutes stretch.
A distant rumble—earthquake? Collapse?
You think, Buried alive down here.
Passengers shift uneasily, some pounding doors.
Sweat drips, chest tight.
Memories surface: loved ones above, oblivious.
Another jolt shakes the car; screams erupt.
You huddle, knees to chest, breathing erratic.
Darkness amplifies every sound—creaks, whispers of panic.
Trapped in this metal coffin, isolation hits hard.
What if oxygen runs out?
Desperation builds; you claw at the window, futile.
The void consumes, anxiety peaking.
Will rescue come, or eternal entombment?

You're hiking a narrow mountain trail at twilight, wind whipping fiercely.
The path crumbles underfoot, pebbles cascading into the abyss below.
Your boot slips, heart leaping to your throat.
You grab a root, dangling precariously over a sheer drop.
Muscles scream, grip weakening.
Below, jagged rocks promise death.
Panic floods; you shout for help, voice lost in the gale.
You think, One wrong move, and it's over.
Arms burn, sweat slicks your hands.
The root creaks ominously.
Flashbacks to life unlived—family, dreams.
Wind howls, pushing you sideways.
You swing a leg up, scraping skin raw.
Adrenaline surges, but fear paralyzes.
Another slip; you catch yourself barely.
Isolation crushes: no one knows your route.
Tears mix with dirt on your face.
Vulnerability raw, you pull up inch by inch, trembling.
Summit distant, night falling.
Dread lingers: will you fall before dawn?
